context_text:
are (v): present plural or present 2nd singular form for 'to be' 
 Example sentences: 
You are very helpful.

They are very nice people.

The neighbors are noisy.

The students are smart.

The parents are worried about their kids.
)

has (v): to own or possess; to get or receive something; to contain or include something; the present 3rd person singular of 'have' 
 Used with nouns: 
She has many things.
(things, clothes, shoes, cars, stories, books, children, items))
 *many additional nouns
He has a cold.
(cold, child, baby, husband, wife, family, job, house, car)
 *many additional nouns
She has no choice.
(choice, money, children, income, experience)

The bread has nuts in it.
(nuts, chocolate, raisins, sugar)
 *many additional nouns Used with adverbs: 
He only has five dollars in his bank account.
(only, just)

She simply has no room at her house.
(simply, absolutely, currently)

My teacher definitely has the flu.
(definitely)

My friend still has my book.
(still)

get (v): to receive; to succeed or achieve; to become 
 Used with nouns: 
The weather is getting warmer.
(weather))

The winner will get his prize tomorrow.
(winner)

He will get another chance tomorrow.
(chance, try)

He got a good education before moving to the US.
(education)

We got approval for our plan.
(approval, authorization, funding)

They got a lot of complaints about the article.
(complaints, feedback)

She gets a lot of enjoyment from doing art.
(enjoyment, fulfillment)

He finally got recognition for his work.
(recognition)

Did you get a receipt?
(receipt)

She got her inspiration while traveling in Europe.
(inspiration, idea)

I finally get a vacation.
(vacation)

We got tickets for the game.
(tickets)

We got instructions on how to complete the task.
(instructions, directions)

She got her degree in English literature.
(degree)

We got an invitation to their wedding.
(invitation)

Did you get my message?
(message)

She got a package in the mail.
(package, magazine, bill, letter, postcard)

He got a scholarship to Harvard.
(scholarship)

She got a warning for her behavior.
(warning)

They got many donations at the event.
(donations)

I hope she gets the hint.
(hint, point, idea)

She got a cramp in her leg.
(cramp, pain, injury)

He got a reward for saving the boy.
(reward)

He got a lot of exposure at the event.
(exposure, publicity)

She got a tan on vacation.
(tan, sunburn)

see (v): to look at or notice something; to understand; to visit 
 Used with adverbs: 
She could see the sunset clearly from her house.
(clearly, easily))

I could hardly see the words on the page without my glasses.
(hardly, barely)

We suddenly could see the boat in the distance.
(suddenly)
 Used with verbs: 
I was able to see the sign.
(be + able to, could)

She went to see her grandmother.
(went to, came to)

He would like to see her win the gold medal.
(would like to, would love to)

I am here to see Lisa Miller.
(be + here to)
 Used with prepositions: 
I can't see into the window because it's so dirty.
(into)

I need to see a doctor about my symptoms.
(about)

need (n): something that someone must have or must do because it is important 
 Used with adjectives: 
There is a great need for smaller class sizes.
(great, big, strong, special, real, true, clear))

There is an overwhelming need for donations at the local food bank.
(overwhelming, urgent, desperate, serious, immediate, sudden)

We have an increasing need for nurses at this hospital.
(increasing, growing, increased)

There is a possible need to reduce staff.
(possible)

How can we meet your individual needs?
(individual, personal)
 Used with verbs: 
I feel the need to do more charity work.
(feel, have)

Voters have expressed the need for more police security.
(expressed, shown, suggested, indicated)

Let's not ignore the needs of the homeless people.
(ignore, deny, overlook)

I am trying to understand your needs?
(understand, meet, consider, support)

know (v): to have information about someone or something; to be familiar with 
 Used with adverbs: 
You know very well what I'm saying.
(very well, full well, perfectly well))

I just knew there would be problems.
(just)

I honestly don't know what you are talking about.
(honestly, really, truly)

I know exactly how you feel.
(exactly, precisely)

I immediately knew what happened.
(immediately, instantly)

I don't know him well, but he seems like a nice guy.
(well, personally)

She hardly knows me.
(hardly, barely)
 Used with verbs: 
Please let me know if you need help.
(let)

I would like to get to know her better.
(get)
 Used with prepositions: 
She knows a lot about science.
(about)

I don't know of anyone who lives in this area.
(of)

would (v): to show the possibility of something; to ask for something 
 Example sentences: 
I would go with you, but I don't have a car.

It would be hotter in here if we didn't have an air conditioner.

I would forget about what he said.

My dad would know how to fix this.

My parents would help us move if they lived closer.

He would know what to do.

How would you do this?

Would you like to come over?

Would you please close the door?

Would you please have a seat?

Would you prefer a window or aisle seat?

Would she like to come with us?
)

find (v): to locate; to discover; to realize or think about something carefully 
 Used with nouns: 
The court found him guilty.
(court, judge, jury, trial))

The study found some interesting results.
(study, scientist, researcher, research, experiment)

The census found some new trends.
(census, poll, report)

He finally found the job he was looking for.
(job, position, opportunity)

They found a lot of problems in his report.
(problems, inaccuracies, differences, errors, flaws)

The police found evidence.
(evidence, fingerprints, footprints, motive, clues, information)

We are trying to find a connection between the events.
(connection, relationship, parallel)

They are working to find a compromise.
(compromise, alternative, solution, replacement, remedy, answer, explanation)

She finds a lot of enjoyment in art.
(enjoyment, love, fulfillment, happiness, joy)

They finally found the survivors.
(survivors, killer, murderer, culprit, victim)

They are trying to find gold.
(gold, treasure, oil)

He wants to find new clients.
(clients, customers)

They finally found the trail they were looking for.
(trail, motel, place, location, things, hotel, spot)

We are trying to find a new apartment.
(apartment, home, house)

We are trying to find the correct route.
(route)

He found a cure for the disease.
(cure)

He finally found the courage to speak his mind.
(courage)

take (v): to get something; to grasp; to consume 
 Used with adverbs: 
She quietly took her friend outside to have a serious talk.
(quietly, privately))
 
Please quickly take this to the other room.
(quickly, carefully)
 
He firmly took her hand and left the room.
(firmly, gently, tenderly)

You need to take this medicine regularly.
(regularly, consistently, frequently, often)
 Used with prepositions: 
She took my comments as criticism.
(as, for)
 Used with nouns: 
Sometimes we need to take advice.
(advice, action)
 
I'm going to take a chance.
(a chance, a risk, a shot)

I need to take a bath.
(bath, shower, break, look, nap, rest, trip, walk)

want (v): to feel that you would like to have, do or get something 
 Used with adverbs: 
He really wants to go to the concert.
(really, desperately))

He just wants a toy car for his birthday.
(just, only, simply)

I truly want you to be happy.
(truly, honestly, sincerely)

She always wants to join us.
(always, never)
 Used with nouns: 
I want an answer.
(answer, apology, adventure, baby, break, divorce, drink, explanation, guarantee, hand, job, promotion, ride)
 *many additional nouns
They want attention.
(attention, forgiveness, freedom, fun, help, justice, proof, protection, reassurance, resolution, respect, revenge, sympathy, trouble)
 *many additional nouns

does (v): to perform an action; the present 3rd person singular of 'do' 
 Example sentences: 
She does her homework before she goes out to play.

She does many after school activities.

He does a lot of chores around the house.

He does the dishes every night.

She does not like me.

She does not want a dog.

He does not understand English.

He does not want to move to another school.
)

learn (v): to gain knowledge or skill; to become aware 
 Used with adverbs: 
I learned a lot from my parents.
(a lot, much))

Some people never learn.
(never)

Will they ever learn?
(ever)

He quickly learned how to do it.
(quickly)
 Used with verbs: 
I need to learn how to cook.
(need to, want to, have to)

She was surprised to learn that I was a teacher.
(be + surprised, be + astonished, be + astounded)
 Used with prepositions: 
The students learned about the Spanish Revolution in history class.
(about)

We first learned of the problem last night.
(of)

The child learns from watching others.
(from, by, through)
 Used with nouns: 
The kids are learning the alphabets.
(alphabets, basics, fundamentals, essentials, language, routine, skills, techniques)
 *many additional nouns
She is learning ballet.
(ballet, grammar, karate, manners, self-control, tricks)
 *many additional nouns

become (v): to begin or start 
 Used with nouns: 
He became an alcoholic at an early age.
(alcoholic, addict))

His problems have become a burden to his family.
(burden, embarrassment)

They became friends in college.
(friends, acquaintances, lovers)

She became a fan after watching her first baseball game.
(fan, follower)

Going home for the holidays has become a tradition.
(tradition)

Having a baby is becoming a reality.
(reality)

He is becoming the focus of the investigation.
(focus)
 Used with adjectives: 
He is becoming great at golf.
(great, good, excellent)

She became sad after she heard the news.
(sad, mad, angry, depressed, unhappy)

She became lonely after her husband passed away.
(lonely, anti-social)

The kids became excited about their trip to Disneyland.
(excited)

come (v): to move towards a person or place; to arrive at a place 
 Used with nouns: 
The bus comes every fifteen minutes.
(bus))

This chance only comes once in a lifetime.
(chance, opportunity)

A hurricane is coming!
(hurricane, tornado, flood)

The mail comes in the afternoon.
(mail)

The announcement came as a shock.
(announcement, message, news)
 Example sentences: 
Come out with your hands up!

Please come over here.

Come to me.

Can you come over to play?

He is coming over soon.

Please come back.

include (v): to have someone or something; a part of something else 
 Used with nouns: 
The email includes an attachment.
(attachment))

The book includes examples of his artwork.
(examples)

The price includes additional features.
(features)

The bill includes last month's charges.
(bill, invoice)

The display includes her earlier artwork.
(display, collection)

The kit includes a small tool.
(kit, manual)

The document includes raw data.
(document, report)
 Used with adverbs: 
They never include us in their plans.
(never, rarely, always, often, frequently, occasionally)
 Used with verbs: 
Try to include everyone if you can.
(try)

Do not include me in the headcount.
(do not, make sure to)

Can you include them, too?
(can)

thank (v): to tell someone that you are grateful 
 Used with adverbs: 
I politely thanked him for his kindness.
(politely, graciously, warmly))

I sincerely thank you for your generous donations.
(sincerely, honestly)

Please properly thank them for their services.
(properly, adequately)
 Used with prepositions: 
He thanked him for all of his hard work.
(for)
 Used with verbs: 
I need to thank everyone for their kindness.
(need to, must, have to want to)

provide (v): to give something that is needed 
 Used with verbs: 
They failed to provide a safe environment.
(failed, tried))

They can provide a good living.
(can, cannot, be + able to, be + unable to)
 Used with nouns: 
My cousin provided me with housing.
(housing, funding, transportation)

She provided the food for camping.
(food, equipment, refreshments)

They provide instruction at school.
(instruction, training, education, opportunities)

Can you provide some proof?
(proof, evidence, references, details, information, answers)

We provide many services at our spa.
(services, treatments)

The trees provide shelter.
(shelter, protection, shade, cover)

We provided them with decent compensation.
(compensation, incentives, accommodations)

The window provided a view of the sea.
(view)

The country provided freedom.
(freedom)

I tried to provide some advice.
(advice, leadership, support)

Can you provide a reason?
(reason, receipt, clue, example, alibi, explanation, alternative, solution)

She provided testimony at the trial.
(testimony)

They provide insurance for employees.
(insurance, coverage, security)

Dogs provide enjoyment for their owners.
(enjoyment, companionship)

The fire provided warmth.
(warmth, heat, light, comfort)

We provided a description to the police.
(description, statement)

The business provided me a good living.
(living, income)

The power plant provides energy to the city.
(energy, electricity)

He always provides me with good input.
(input, feedback, criticism)
 Used with adverbs: 
She kindly provided warm blankets to the cold children.
(kindly)
 Used with prepositions: 
I cannot provide for my family.
(for)

We provide food to homeless shelters.
(to)

The teachers provided the students with school supplies.
(with)

create (v): to make something 
 Used with nouns: 
The architect created a work of art.
(architect, artist, sculptor, painter))

The economy will create new jobs.
(economy)

The programmer will create advanced software.
(programmer)

She created an account.
(account, blog, blueprint, costume, document, game, painting, picture, product, recipe, software, website)

Don't create alarm.
(alarm, anxiety, bitterness, chaos, distrust, jealousy, panic, resentment, conflict)

The goal is to create competition.
(competition, demand, harmony, opportunities, wealth, work)
 Used with adverbs: 
She quickly created a game to pass the time.
(quickly)

He successfully created a new product for his company.
(successfully)

The economy suddenly created new jobs.
(suddenly)

He purposely created a scene in public.
(purposely, intentionally)

add (v): to put something with something else 
 Used with adverbs: 
He thoughtfully added 'I love you.'
(thoughtfully, softly))

She quickly added the remaining ingredients.
(quickly, carefully)

The preschooler masterfully added 2 and 2.
(masterfully, easily)
 Used with nouns: 
Please add your comments at the bottom.
(comments, suggestions, recommendations, remarks)

Add the numbers together for the total.
(numbers)

Try adding more salt to the soup.
(salt, pepper, seasoning, flavor)

Let's add chairs to the room.
(chairs, tables, furniture)
 Used with verbs: 
He cannot add yet.
(cannot)

You should add more salt. It's bland.
(should, need to, must)

understand (v): to know what something means or how something works; to know how something feels 
 Used with adverbs: 
He fully understands what is going on.
(fully, completely, totally, clearly, really, truly))

He barely understands what the teacher is saying.
(barely, hardly)

She finally understood the directions.
(finally)

He immediately understood the danger he was in.
(immediately, quickly, suddenly)

Help me to better understand the situation.
(better)

He does not really understand why she is so mad.
(not really, not truly, not necessarily, not entirely)
 Used with verbs: 
He seems to understand English.
(seems to, appears to)

Can you understand the question?
(can, do)

You have to understand that I had no choice.
(have, must)
 Used with prepositions: 
She does not understand much about politics.
(about)
 Used with nouns: 
He doesn't understand the business.
(business, basics, concept, danger, difference, importance, need, language, meaning, problem, reason, significance, situation)

consider (v): to think about 
 Used with adverbs: 
Please carefully consider your options.
(carefully, seriously, strongly))

I did briefly consider quitting my job.
(briefly)

I never considered moving an option.
(never)

Have you ever considered retiring?
(ever)
 Used with prepositions: 
They are considering me for the job.
(for)
 Used with nouns: 
We must consider the facts.
(facts, evidence, idea, issue, options, problem, topic)
 Used with verbs: 
We must consider all of the evidence.
(must, need to, have to)

We should consider him for the position.
(should, ought to)

choose (v): to decide which person or thing you want; to decide to do something 
 Used with adverbs: 
Make sure you choose carefully.
(carefully, wisely, well))

They can voluntarily choose to leave at any time.
(voluntarily, freely, willingly)

We intentionally chose this house because of the neighborhood.
(intentionally, deliberately, purposely, specifically)

I randomly chose a partner for the activity.
(randomly, reluctantly)
 Used with verbs: 
He is able to choose for himself.
(be + able, be + free, can)
 Used with prepositions: 
Can you choose between these two shirts?
(between, from)

develop (v): to build or grow 
 Used with adverbs: 
The child is developing abnormally in the womb.
(abnormally))

She naturally developed curly hair as she got older.
(naturally)

Children develop quickly.
(quickly, rapidly)
 Used with nouns: 
The disease will develop over time.
(disease, firm, friendship, industry, market, relationship, situation, team, technology)

She is trying to develop her ability.
(ability, confidence, creativity, ideas, identity, skills, style, talent)

remember (v): to recall; to keep something in your memory 
 Used with nouns: 
I cannot remember his birthday.
(birthday, anniversary, name))

I don't remember much of my dream.
(dream, childhood)

I can't remember the joke.
(joke, password)

I remember the time that we went to the beach.
(time)

I do not remember that conversation.
(conversation, incident, event, episode)
 Used with adverbs: 
I clearly remember how to get there.
(clearly, still, barely, hardly, vaguely)

I remember precisely what she said.
(precisely, exactly, vividly, distinctly)

I will always remember you.
(always, especially)

She finally remembered to call me.
(finally, suddenly)

I can remember back to the 1940s.
(back)

I will remember this forever.
(forever, fondly, well)
 Used with verbs: 
I cannot remember his name.
(cannot, can)
 Used with prepositions: 
She remembered him as a little boy.
(as)

He is remembered for his funny jokes.
(for)

Did you remember to lock the door?
(to)

She will be remembered for her charm.
(for)

He will be remembered as a great man.
(as)

determine (v): to find out; to cause or decide an outcome 
 Used with adverbs: 
We are trying to determine exactly what happened.
(exactly, precisely))

The teacher needs to objectively determine who was wrong.
(objectively)

His decision will ultimately determine whether she gets the job.
(ultimately)

Can you accurately determine the root cause?
(accurately, directly)

A test score can largely determine your choices for college.
(largely)
 Used with nouns: 
Who will determine the champion?
(champion, winner, future, outcome)

We will determine the distance.
(distance, effect, identity, rate, ratio, risk, scope, sex, shape, size, type, value, volume, wage)

grow (v): to increase; to develop; to get bigger; to produce 
 Used with adverbs: 
Bamboo grows really fast.
(fast, quickly, rapidly))

Demand has grown considerably this year.
(considerably, dramatically, significantly, substantially)

He seems to be growing slowly.
(slowly)

Business has only grown slightly this year.
(slightly)

Sales have grown steadily since they opened the new store.
(steadily, constantly, continuously)

I'm concerned she's not growing normally.
(normally)

The garden is growing well with all this warm weather.
(well)

I don't know why my plants are growing so poorly.
(poorly)

The produce is grown locally.
(locally, organically, commercially)

She successfully grows her own vegetables.
(successfully)
 Used with verbs: 
The garden seems to grow slowly.
(seems, continues)

Their business began to grow quickly.
(began, started)
 Used with prepositions: 
The city is growing at a record pace.
(at)

Revenue is expected to grow by 5% next year.
(by)

The small plant quickly grew into a large tree.
(into)

It only takes a couple of years for puppies to grow to adult size.
(to)

We grew these flowers from seed.
(from)
 Used with nouns: 
Her anxiety grew while she waited.
(anxiety, anger, fear, curiosity, excitement, impatience, irritation)

Babies grow so quickly.
(babies, puppies, kittens, children)

The produce grew slowly.
(produce, crops)

His farm grew over the years.
(farm, collection)

His popularity grew rapidly.
(popularity, fame)

The industry is growing steadily.
(industry, business, company, market, economy, deficit, city)

The population is growing continuously.
(population)

She is growing a garden this year.
(garden)

He is trying to grow a beard.
(beard)

The roots grew under the sidewalk.
(roots)

allow (v): to let someone do something or let something happen 
 Used with nouns: 
The security guard would not allow entrance to the building.
(entrance, admittance, access, clearance))

The dormitory does not allow smoking.
(smoking, drinking, pets, visitors)

Loose clothing allows more comfort.
(comfort, movement, flexibility, freedom)

Her schedule does not allow time for fun.
(time)
 Example sentences: 
Do not allow them inside.

You are not allowed to see him anymore.

I cannot allow that to happen.

Who allowed this?

Are you allowed in here?

They aren't allowed to do anything.

supply (n): an amount of something that is available to be used; things that are needed by a particular group of people 
 Used with adjectives: 
There is an endless supply of paper in his office.
(endless, never-ending, infinite, unending, unlimited))

We have a good supply of water for emergencies.
(good, large, abundant, adequate, sufficient, ample)

He has an excessive supply of guns in his basement.
(excessive, extravagant)

They need a constant supply of fresh water.
(constant, continuous, regular, steady)

The hotel provides a fresh supply of clean towels every day.
(fresh, new)

The accident cut off blood supply to her brain.
(blood, air, oxygen)

Where can I buy art supplies?
(art)

Our church donated medical supplies to the poor country.
(medical)

I have to go shopping for school supplies.
(school)

The fire left the family without any basic supplies.
(basic)
 Used with verbs: 
We have a good supply of clean water.
(have)

The farmer produces the largest supply of dairy products in this area.
(produces, makes, provides)

The earthquake cut off our city's power supply.
(cut off, disconnected, stopped, halted)

We depleted our food supply before the camping trip was over.
(depleted, exhausted, used up, ran out of)

I need to refill my supply of paper and pencils before school starts.
(refill, restore, restock, replenish)

We are trying to reduce our supply of plastic bottles.
(reduce, limit, control)

We need to increase our supply of firewood before winter.
(increase)
 Used with nouns: 
All of our office products are in the supply room.
(room, closet)
 Used with prepositions: 
We need a supply of fresh towels.
( of)

bring (v): to come to a place with someone or something 
 Used with adverbs: 
I will gladly bring my new wife to the party.
(gladly, happily))
 Used with nouns: 
Please bring me the check.
(check, money)

He brings chaos wherever he goes.
(chaos, confusion, disorder, disaster, trouble)

I hope the verdict will bring them closure.
(closure, comfort)

The baby brings the new parents enjoyment.
(enjoyment, happiness, joy)

The rescue workers bring great hope to the devastated area.
(hope)

She brought bad news.
(news)

Please bring help!
(help, aid, assistance)

She will bring a guest to the wedding.
(guest)

improve (v): to make something better 
 Used with adverbs: 
His health improved dramatically over the weekend.
(dramatically, considerably, significantly, greatly, tremendously, remarkably, noticeably))

John's writing has definitely improved this year.
(definitely, certainly, consistently, continually, gradually, steadily)

The road conditions quickly improved overnight.
(quickly, rapidly)
 Used with verbs: 
The weather should continue to improve tonight.
(continue, begin)

He is trying to improve his skills.
(be + trying, be + hoping)

Help me improve my grades.
(help)
 Used with nouns: 
His condition improved.
(condition, circumstances, health, situation, symptoms)

I hope the economy improves.
(economy, quality, service, weather)

How can we improve our appearance?
(appearance, atmosphere, attendance, chances, communication, conditions, grades, health, image, knowledge, performance, productivity, relationship, scores, situation, skills)

maintain (v): to keep at the same level or condition 
 Used with verbs: 
I want to maintain my blood pressure level.
(want, need, try, have))

Communication helps to maintain a good relationship.
(helps)
 Used with nouns: 
She was able to maintain her dignity through the difficult moments.
(dignity, confidence, strength, composure, integrity, control)

Maintain pressure on the wound for at least a minute.
(pressure)

He maintained his position throughout the argument.
(position, perspective, innocence, dominance, distance)

She did not maintain her friendship.
(friendship, relationship, connections, independence, health)

They were able to maintain their discipline.
(discipline, credibility, momentum, sanity)

Who maintains the database for you?
(database, garden, grounds, lawn, website)

She maintains her weight well.
(weight, appearance, image)

How do you maintain peace in a relationship?
(peace, trust, honesty)

He couldn't maintain his lifestyle on his limited income.
(lifestyle, household, house)

It's important to maintain our family tradition.
(tradition)
 Used with adverbs: 
The house was properly maintained.
(properly, well, poorly, carefully)

The hotel normally maintains a higher level of standard.
(normally, typically, usually)

She seems to easily maintain a balance between school and work.
(easily, successfully)

begin (v): to start 
 Used with adverbs: 
The play will begin soon.
(soon, shortly))

The fireworks suddenly began to go off.
(suddenly, immediately, quickly)

After a rain delay, the game will finally begin.
(finally)

The musicians slowly began to play.
(slowly, gradually)

We began the show again.
(again, all over again)
 Used with verbs: 
The show is expected to begin at noon.
(be + expected, be + due, be + scheduled)

Will you be ready to begin on time?
(be ready)

The show is going to begin soon.
(be + going)
 Used with prepositions: 
The party will begin with dancing.
(with)

We need to begin by noon.
(by, at)

Did the ceremony begin on time?
(on)

exist (v): to be real, to live 
 Used with adverbs: 
They argued about whether aliens actually exist.
(actually, really, truly))

Few pandas still exist in the wild.
(still, currently)

I think something like that already exists.
(already)

Dinosaurs no longer exist.
(no longer)

It seems like that company only exists to hurt people.
(only, solely)
 Used with verbs: 
In just a few years, wild tigers may cease to exist.
(cease to)

These creatures appear to exist only in this spot.
(appear to, be + believed to, be + known to)

Many buildings will continue to exist long after being abandoned.
(continue to)
 Used with nouns: 
We are investigating if alternatives exist.
(alternatives)

Many problems exist in his proposal.
(problems, challenges, discrepancies)

These traditions exist for a reason.
(traditions, customs, laws, rules)

(badly, terribly, uncontrollably))

I was so nervous that I was almost shaking.
(almost, practically, visibly, literally, physically)

My hands were shaking nervously during my speech.
(nervously)

The earth shook suddenly.
(suddenly, quickly, violently)

Shake well before opening.
(well, gently)

They firmly shook hands.
(firmly, warmly)
 Used with prepositions: 
My body was shaking from the cold.
(from)

She was shaking with anger.
(with, in)

He was shaking his head at them.
(at)
 Used with nouns: 
The news shook her confidence.
(confidence, faith)

He shook the dirt off his jacket.
(dirt, dust)

He shook his head at them.
(head, finger)

They shook hands before the meeting.
(hands)

shift (v): to move to a different place or position 
 Used with verbs:

 Used with adverbs:

(into, to)
 Used with nouns:

(attention, eyes, focus)

He tried to shift his responsibility onto others.
(responsibility, blame)

(balance, weight)

shine (v): to make a bright light 
 Used with adverbs:

steal (n): something sold at a very low price

)

sail (v): to travel on water in a boat 
 Used with adverbs: 
The boat sailed gracefully.
(gracefully, quickly, smoothly))

The ship sailed away.
(away, back, off, on, out, past)
 Used with prepositions: 
He sailed across the ocean.
(across, into)

We sailed around the world.
(around)

The ferry sailed for three hours.
(for)

She is sailing from London.
(from, to)
 Used with nouns: 
The ship sailed to Australia.
(ship, boat, ferry, vessel, yacht)

scheme (v): to plan something clever 
 Used with adverbs: 
They are secretly scheming to take over the company.
(secretly, quietly, privately))

He is always scheming of ways to get control of the business.
(always, constantly)

script (n): the written form of a play or movie 
 Used with adjectives: 
He submitted his original script.
(original, final, latest))

This is a very good script.
(good, great, well-written, nice, funny, exciting, creative)
 Used with verbs: 
The author prepared the script for the readers.
(prepared, wrote)

The class read the script together.
(read, co-wrote, rewrote, planned, acted out)
 Used with nouns: 
The script editor was very pleased with the work.
(editor, writer, reader)
 Used with prepositions: 
It is a script about a farmer's life.
(about)

Here is a script for a children's TV show.
(for)

slight (adj): very small; thin 
 Used with verbs: 
The injury was slight.
(be: was/were, seemed, appeared))
 Used with adverbs: 
The mistake was very slight.
(very, fairly, relatively)
 Used with nouns: 
She has a slight accent.
(accent, bruise, burn, bump, cold, disadvantage, advantage, fever, headache, injury)

There was a slight accident.
(accident, breeze, chance, chill, decline, decrease, defect, delay, dent, difference, increase, misunderstanding, miscalculation, noise, problem)

We made a slight adjustment.
(adjustment, alteration, change, improvement, modification)

We had a slight disagreement.
(disagreement)

smart (adj): intelligent 
 Used with verbs: 
She is very smart.
(be: is/am/are, sounds, looks, seems))

They are getting smarter about their finances.
(be + getting, be + becoming)

This class will make you smarter.
(make)
 Used with adverbs: 
Her son is extremely smart.
(extremely, fairly, very)

He's smart enough to know what to do.
(enough)
 Used with nouns: 
He is a very smart boy.
(boy, person, student, guy)

You made a smart choice.
(choice, decision, move)

We need to hire more smart people.
(people)

sock (n): a piece of clothing you wear on your foot 
 Used with adjectives: 
She likes to wear long socks.
(long, knee-high, short, thick, thin))

His mother yelled at him for leaving his dirty socks on the floor.
(dirty, old, smelly, gym, sweat)

He needs to buy a pair of dress socks.
(dress, cotton, wool, white)
 Used with verbs: 
I told my son to pull up his socks.
(pull up, pick up)

She pulls off her socks as soon as she gets home.
(pulls off)

My grandmother knitted a pair of socks for me.
(knitted)
 Used with nouns: 
His sock drawer was filled with dress socks.
(drawer)

She entertained the children by using sock puppets.
(puppets)

station (n): a place where public transportation regularly stops to let passengers on and off; a place where a particular service is offered; a radio or television company 
 Used with adjectives: 
I will pick him up at the train station.
(train, bus, subway))

We need to get off at the next station.
(next)

I feel safe with the police station across the street.
(police, fire)

He works at a gas station.
(gas)

That's my favorite radio station.
(radio, television, TV, local, news)
 Used with verbs: 
We got to the station too late.
(got to, went to, arrived at)

The bus will leave the station at 11am.
(leave)

The train arrived at the Main Station an hour late.
(arrived at)

He runs the gas station in the evenings.
(runs, operates, closes, opens)

I listen to this radio station on my way to work.
(listen to, tune into)

The radio station broadcasts classical music.
(broadcasts, airs, plays)
 Used with nouns: 
Let's meet at the station parking lot.
(parking lot)

I ran into him in the station building.
(building)

He is the gas station manager.
(manager, owner, attendant)
 Used with prepositions: 
We are getting off at the next station.
(at)

toe (n): one of the five parts at the end of a foot 
 Used with adjectives: 
Babies have little toes.
(little, tiny, small, cute))

He has a broken toe.
(broken, injured, stubbed)

He hurt his big toe.
(big, pinky)
 Used with verbs: 
She stubbed her toe on the coffee table.
(stubbed, hit, bumped, broke)

Can you wiggle your toes?
(wiggle, move, feel)

She dipped her toes in the water.
(dipped, put)
 Used with prepositions: 
She stood on her tiptoes.
(on)

I like to feel the sand between my toes.
(between)

tower (v): to stand taller than others 
 Used with adverbs: 
The school star basketball player towers greatly over the other students.
(greatly, impressively, remarkably))

The elephant massively towered over the little mouse.
(massively, hugely)
 Used with prepositions: 
The basketball player towered over his teammates.
(over)

truck (n): a big, heavy vehicle used for carrying things 
 Used with adjectives: 
We need a moving truck.
(moving, big, huge, large))

I have a pickup truck you can use.
(pickup, flatbed)
 
The fire trucks are on their way.
(fire)

I had to call a tow truck because my car wouldn't start.
(tow)

The little boy likes to play with his toy truck.
(toy)
 Used with verbs: 
We loaded the moving truck.
(loaded, unloaded)

She has a hard time driving a big truck.
(driving, parking)

The truck is carrying fuel.
(be + carrying, be + hauling)
 Used with nouns: 
The truck driver has been on the road all night long.
(driver)

He rested at the truck stop.
(stop)

The truckload was too heavy for the road.
(load)

witness (v): to see something happen and be able to describe it to others or in a court of law; to be able to prove an official document has been signed by someone 
 Used with nouns: 
She witnessed the crime.
(crime, horror, scene, violence))

The little girl witnessed the death of her grandfather.
(death, decline)

We witnessed the greatest event ever.
(event, act)

The victim's family witnessed the execution of the murderer.
(execution)

We have witnessed an improvement in her behavior these days.
(improvement)

He witnessed the murder of his friend.
(murder, suffering)

We have witnessed a miracle.
(miracle)
